results.justification: The study explicitly states it employs a 'quantitative ethnography' methodology, integrating qualitative and quantitative methods (Section 3).
Sections 2.1-2.3 detail the course design, research questions, participants, and data sources, providing a step-by-step description of the study design.
The document does not state that the raw or processed datasets are publicly available.
While the document doesn't explicitly state a reason for not sharing data, it doesn't offer a justification either.
Section 3.1 describes the coding process and mentions a consolidated list of textual expressions matched to codes, functioning as a data dictionary (though not fully detailed).
Data collection methods are described in Section 2.2 and 2.3, detailing the use of online forum discussions and assignment performance records.
The document does not state that the analysis code is shared in an open repository.
There is no justification provided for why the code is not shared.
Section 3.1 mentions the use of Excel formulas for counting code occurrences, indicating code was used for data preparation, and the process is described.
Statistical tests (t-tests) and models (ENA, ONA) are described in Sections 3.2 and 1.3.
Effect sizes (Cohen’s d) and p-values are reported in Table 2 and throughout Section 4.
The document provides subjective context and interpretation of the results, particularly in the discussion section (Section 4).
The coding process is described in Section 3.1, and the use of instructor-identified keywords as codes is explained.
Results are clearly presented in figures (Fig. 1, Fig. 2, Fig. 3, Fig. 4) and tables (Table 2), with accompanying textual explanations.
Section 4 discusses limitations, such as not investigating factors beyond performance scores and the need for further research on barriers to activation of knowledge resources.
The document does not contain a link to a preregistration.
